questions.text: A 32-year-old professional surfer presents with complaints of reduced hearing and recurrent water trapping in the left ear. Otoscopic examination reveals as image as shown below. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Surgical excision with canaloplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exostoses are benign bony outgrowths of the external auditory canal typically seen in individuals exposed to cold water. Definitive management in symptomatic cases is surgical excision with canaloplasty .
  • ➤ surgical excision with canaloplasty

questions.text: A 32-year-old IV drug user presents with fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, and jaundice. Further testing reveals a chronic viral hepatitis infection. Regarding hepatitis viruses and their clinical implications, which of the following statements are incorrect? Hepatitis A virus is associated with chronic liver disease and is commonly acquired via blood transfusion. Hepatitis E infection is particularly severe in pregnant women and may lead to fulminant liver failure. Hepatitis C is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route and carries a high risk of progression to chronic hepatitis. Hepatitis B and D can coinfect simultaneously or HDV can superinfect an HBV carrier; superinfection tends to be more severe. Hepatitis B is parenterally transmitted and causes chronic infection in a minority of patients.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HAV and HCV differ in transmission routes—HAV is fecal-oral and never chronic; HCV is parenteral and frequently chronic. HDV requires HBV for replication and causes more severe disease in superinfection.
  • ➤ HAV and HCV differ in transmission routes—HAV is fecal-oral and never chronic; HCV is parenteral and frequently chronic.
  • ➤ HDV requires HBV for replication and causes more severe disease in superinfection.

questions.text: A 72-year-old retired professor from Kolkata is brought to the neurology clinic by his daughter due to progressive memory problems and difficulty managing daily tasks over the past year. He has started missing bill payments, repeating questions, and often gets lost in familiar surroundings. Recently, he was found wandering outside his house late at night, confused about the time and place. He struggles to recognize distant relatives and misplaces important items, believing others have stolen them. His family reports a history of similar cognitive decline in his father. He has no tremors, hallucinations, or abnormal movements. Investigations: Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE): 18/30 (suggesting moderate cognitive impairment) What is the most likely underlying pathological change?

options.label: A
options.text: Aberrant deposits of alpha-synuclein protein in the primary motor cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the basal ganglia striatum

options.label: C
options.text: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert

questions.correct_answer: D. Loss of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Loss of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and involves degeneration of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert , leading to acetylcholine deficiency . Hallmark pathological findings include amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles . Management includes cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and memantine for symptomatic relief.
  • ➤ Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and involves degeneration of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert , leading to acetylcholine deficiency .
  • ➤ Alzheimer’s disease
  • ➤ degeneration of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert
  • ➤ acetylcholine deficiency
  • ➤ Hallmark pathological findings include amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles .
  • ➤ amyloid plaques
  • ➤ tau protein tangles
  • ➤ Management includes cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and memantine for symptomatic relief.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of renal transplantation presents with malaise, fever, and rising serum creatinine. Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has had bone pain, worse in the spine and ribs, for 3 months. His mother passed away from lung cancer at the age of 67. He has mild pallor and multiple bruises all over his body. Investigations: Haemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL Serum calcium: 11.36 mg/dL Blood film: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder that presents with the CRAB symptoms (calcium, renal, anaemia, bleeding, bones, infection), and it often causes bone pain (especially in the spine and ribs), hypercalcaemia , anaemia , and renal impairment . Rouleaux formation on the blood film is a classic finding in multiple myeloma , due to increased immunoglobulins in the blood. The treatment of multiple myeloma involves chemotherapy , stem cell transplantation , and bisphosphonates to manage bone pain and hypercalcaemia .
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder that presents with the CRAB symptoms (calcium, renal, anaemia, bleeding, bones, infection), and it often causes bone pain (especially in the spine and ribs), hypercalcaemia , anaemia , and renal impairment .

  • ➤ hypercalcaemia
  • ➤ anaemia
  • ➤ renal impairment
  • ➤ Rouleaux formation on the blood film is a classic finding in multiple myeloma , due to increased immunoglobulins in the blood.
  • ➤ Rouleaux formation
  • ➤ classic finding
  • ➤ multiple myeloma
  • ➤ immunoglobulins
  • ➤ The treatment of multiple myeloma involves chemotherapy , stem cell transplantation , and bisphosphonates to manage bone pain and hypercalcaemia .
  • ➤ multiple myeloma
  • ➤ chemotherapy

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. On post-operative day 3, she develops fever, right upper quadrant pain, and signs of sepsis. questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strasberg classification categorizes bile duct injuries during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Type C injury is defined as transection without ligation of an aberrant right hepatic duct , commonly resulting in postoperative bile leaks requiring drainage and definitive biliary repair.
  • ➤ Strasberg classification categorizes bile duct injuries during laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • ➤ Type C injury is defined as transection without ligation of an aberrant right hepatic duct , commonly resulting in postoperative bile leaks requiring drainage and definitive biliary repair.

  • ➤ transection without ligation
  • ➤ aberrant right hepatic duct
  • ➤ Strasberg Classification:
  • ➤ Strasberg Classification:
  • ➤ Type A - Injury to the cystic duct or from minor hepatic ducts draining the liver bed.
  • ➤ Type B - Occlusion of biliary tree, commonly aberrant right hepatic duct(s)
  • ➤ Type C - Transection without ligation of aberrant right hepatic duct(s)
  • ➤ Type D - Lateral injury to a major bile duct.
  • ➤ Type E (1-5) - Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to level of injury (i.e., below). E1 (Bismuth type 1) - Injury more than 2 cm from confluence
  • ➤ E2 (Bismuth type 2) - Injury less than 2 cm from confluence
  • ➤ E3 (Bismuth type 3) - Injury at the confluence; confluence intact
  • ➤ E4 (Bismuth type 4) - Destruction of the biliary confluence

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with complaints of loss of interest, fatigue, insomnia, and recurrent feelings of worthlessness. She also reports hearing a voice telling her she is a burden on her family. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Psychotic depression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psychotic depression is characterized by the presence of depressive symptoms with delusions/hallucinations. Psychotic symptoms can be mood congruent/mood incongruent. If the content of delusions/hallucinations matches the mood, it's called mood congruent; if it doesn't match, it's called mood incongruent. For example, a patient with severe depression develops a delusion that the world is ending. It is an example of mood-congruent delusion.
  • ➤ Psychotic depression is characterized by the presence of depressive symptoms with delusions/hallucinations.
  • ➤ Psychotic symptoms can be mood congruent/mood incongruent. If the content of delusions/hallucinations matches the mood, it's called mood congruent; if it doesn't match, it's called mood incongruent.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is undergoing renal evaluation using a test substance administered intravenously. Analysis of blood samples reveals the substance is present in the renal artery but undetectable in the renal vein. Based on this observation, which of the following is most accurate regarding the clearance of this substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow

options.label: B
options.text: It must be reabsorbed by the kidney

options.label: C
options.text: Its clearance is equal to the glomerular filtration rate

options.label: D
options.text: Its urinary concentration must be higher than its plasma concentration

questions.correct_answer: A. Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When a substance is present in the renal artery but completely absent in the renal vein , this means that 100% of the plasma that entered the kidney has been cleared of the substance . The only way this occurs is if the substance is filtered and completely secreted into the urine without any reabsorption , and none of it returns to circulation.
  • • present in the renal artery but completely absent in the renal vein
  • • 100% of the plasma that entered the kidney has been cleared of the substance
  • • filtered and completely secreted
  • • without any reabsorption
  • • This is the defining characteristic of a substance whose clearance equals the renal plasma flow (RPF) .
  • • clearance equals the renal plasma flow (RPF)
  • • A classic example is para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) . PAH is filtered at the glomerulus and actively secreted by the proximal tubules into the renal tubule, such that nearly all PAH entering the kidney is excreted in urine. Because no PAH is found in the renal vein , the clearance of PAH equals the renal plasma flow under these ideal conditions.
  • • para-aminohippuric acid (PAH)
  • • actively secreted
  • • renal vein
  • • clearance of PAH equals the renal plasma flow
  • • This directly corresponds to the original question:
  • • "If a substance appears in the renal artery but not in the renal vein" → then its clearance is equal to renal plasma flow .
  • • renal plasma flow
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. It must be reabsorbed by the kidney: If a substance were reabsorbed , it would re-enter the blood and thus appear in the renal vein . The fact that it does not appear in the renal vein means no reabsorption has occurred , making this option false.
  • • Option B. It must be reabsorbed by the kidney:
  • • reabsorbed
  • • renal vein
  • • not appear in the renal vein
  • • no reabsorption has occurred
  • • Option C. Its clearance is equal to the glomerular filtration rate: Clearance equals glomerular filtration rate (GFR) only if the substance is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted (e.g., inulin ). In this case, the substance is cleared completely , implying both filtration and secretion , and thus clearance is greater than GFR—equaling renal plasma flow .
  • • Option C. Its clearance is equal to the glomerular filtration rate:
  • • glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
  • • freely filtered
  • • neither reabsorbed nor secreted
  • • inulin
  • • cleared completely
  • • both filtration and secretion
  • • renal plasma flow
  • • Option D. Its urinary concentration must be higher than its plasma concentration: While the urinary concentration may be higher, this is not sufficient or necessary to determine clearance . Clearance depends on the volume of plasma from which the substance is removed, not simply the concentration in urine. This statement does not explain why the substance is absent in the renal vein , so it is not the correct answer.
  • • Option D. Its urinary concentration must be higher than its plasma concentration:
  • • urinary concentration
  • • not sufficient or necessary
  • • clearance
  • • not explain
  • • absent in the renal vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a substance is present in the renal artery but completely absent in the renal vein, its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow. This is a hallmark of substances that are fully excreted by the kidney, such as para-aminohippuric acid.

questions.text: A neonate presents with progressive lethargy, poor feeding, and vomiting within 48 hours of birth.   • ➤ CPS-1
  • ➤ rate-limiting enzyme
  • ➤ urea cycle

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the dermatology clinic by his mother due to multiple asymptomatic skin lesions. On examination, there are numerous small, shiny, discrete, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules measuring 1–2 mm in diameter distributed over the dorsal surface of the hands, forearms, and shaft of the penis. There is no itching and no mucosal involvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lichen nitidus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lichen nitidus is a rare chronic dermatosis that commonly affects children and young adults. It presents as:
  • • Lichen nitidus
  • • Multiple, shiny, flesh-colored or pink dome-shaped papules (1–2 mm) Commonly distributed over flexural areas, forearms, hands, trunk, and genitalia Asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic Absence of Wickham’s striae Histopathology shows a characteristic "ball-and-claw" appearance due to lymphohistiocytic infiltration in dermal papillae
  • • Multiple, shiny, flesh-colored or pink dome-shaped papules (1–2 mm)
  • • Commonly distributed over flexural areas, forearms, hands, trunk, and genitalia
  • • Asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic
  • • Absence of Wickham’s striae
  • • Histopathology shows a characteristic "ball-and-claw" appearance due to lymphohistiocytic infiltration in dermal papillae
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Molluscum contagiosum:
  • • Option A. Molluscum contagiosum:
  • • Also presents with dome-shaped papules, but they are typically larger with central umbilication. Lesions may contain a curd-like substance and show Henderson-Patterson bodies histologically.
  • • Also presents with dome-shaped papules, but they are typically larger with central umbilication.
  • • Lesions may contain a curd-like substance and show Henderson-Patterson bodies histologically.
  • • Option B. Scabies:
  • • Option B. Scabies:
  • • Presents with intense pruritus, especially at night. Burrows and papular eruptions are seen in web spaces, axillae, and groin. Genital involvement may be seen, but itching and excoriations are typical.
  • • Presents with intense pruritus, especially at night.
  • • Burrows and papular eruptions are seen in web spaces, axillae, and groin.
  • • Genital involvement may be seen, but itching and excoriations are typical.
  • • Option C. Lichen planus:
  • • Option C. Lichen planus:
  • • Characterized by pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules. Wickham’s striae are typically present. Mucosal involvement is common.
  • • Characterized by pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules.
  • • Wickham’s striae are typically present.
  • • Mucosal involvement is common.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen nitidus should be considered in children presenting with multiple tiny, shiny, flesh-colored papules localized to the forearms, hands, and genitalia without pruritus or Wickham’s striae.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with a history of Alzheimer’s disease presents with a 3-month history of increased urinary urgency, daytime frequency, and occasional urge incontinence. questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted with a pulmonary embolism and started on intravenous unfractionated heparin. questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding salivary gland tumors is/are true? Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland and contains both epithelial and mesenchymal components on histology. Warthin tumor typically affects elderly males and histologically shows mucin-producing and squamous cells. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma can involve the facial nerve, and its malignant potential depends on the proportion of epidermoid elements. Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a high propensity for perineural spread and recurrence; facial paralysis is frequently observed. Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for all high-grade malignant parotid tumors.

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1 woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of decreased fetal movements for 2 days. She has a history of a previous term stillbirth. questions.text: A microbiology lab is evaluating an isolate suspected to be Candida albicans. questions.text: In a patient with history of trauma of forearm and X-ray showing fracture of proximal part of medial bone with dislocation of proximal part of lateral bone. Which of the following muscles may be paralyzed?

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Urticaria Pigmentosa and Darier’s disease are true? Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common form of cutaneous mastocytosis and is due to mast cell accumulation in the skin. Darier’s sign, seen in urticaria pigmentosa, is elicited by firm stroking that leads to increased induration or piloerection. Darier’s disease presents with greasy, dirty-appearing papules on the trunk and flexures, and nail changes like red and white longitudinal streaks. A point mutation in the c-KIT proto-oncogene plays a role in the pathogenesis of urticaria pigmentosa. Pseudo-Darier sign is classically seen in urticaria pigmentosa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Statement 1: True – Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common variant of cutaneous mastocytosis and is due to dermal mast cell accumulation.
  • • Statement 1:
  • • Statement 3: True – Darier’s disease presents with keratotic papules on seborrheic areas and flexures, with characteristic nail findings including longitudinal red/white lines and distal notching.
  • • Statement 3:
  • • Statement 4: True – The c-KIT mutation is implicated in urticaria pigmentosa.
  • • Statement 4:
  • • Incorrect Statements:
  • • Incorrect Statements:
  • • Statement 2: False – This describes the Pseudo-Darier sign, which is seen in smooth muscle hamartoma. True Darier’s sign is urtication and erythema after rubbing the lesion, seen in urticaria pigmentosa.
  • • Statement 2:
  • • Statement 5: False – Pseudo-Darier sign is seen in smooth muscle hamartoma , not in urticaria pigmentosa.
  • • Statement 5:
  • • smooth muscle hamartoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urticaria pigmentosa is a mast cell disorder presenting with brown macules that urticate upon stroking (Darier’s sign). It is associated with c-KIT mutations. Darier’s disease, on the other hand, is a keratinization disorder with flexural papules, nail changes, and oral mucosal lesions, and should not be confused with Darier’s sign.
  • ➤ Urticaria pigmentosa is a mast cell disorder presenting with brown macules that urticate upon stroking (Darier’s sign). It is associated with c-KIT mutations.
  • ➤ Darier’s disease, on the other hand, is a keratinization disorder with flexural papules, nail changes, and oral mucosal lesions, and should not be confused with Darier’s sign.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She has a sedentary lifestyle and a BMI of 26. She has a history of smoking one pack per day but recently quit. At her last visit, she was advised to take calcium and vitamin D supplements but has not been compliant. A DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.5, indicating osteoporosis. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment for postmenopausal women diagnosed with osteoporosis (T-score ≤ -2.5). These medications reduce bone resorption and increase bone density, significantly lowering fracture risk. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are essential adjunct therapies but are not sufficient as standalone treatment for osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment for postmenopausal women diagnosed with osteoporosis (T-score ≤ -2.5).
  • ➤ These medications reduce bone resorption and increase bone density, significantly lowering fracture risk.
  • ➤ Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are essential adjunct therapies but are not sufficient as standalone treatment for osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman from Chennai, recently diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma, presents to the emergency department with generalised weakness, reduced urine output, and increasing confusion over the past 24 hours. She had completed her first cycle of chemotherapy two weeks ago. On examination, she is lethargic, mildly dehydrated, and shows no signs of active infection. questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS) is a potentially fatal complication of chemotherapy for highly proliferative cancers like Burkitt lymphoma . It results from the rapid breakdown of tumour cells, leading to hyperuricaemia , hyperkalemia , hyperphosphatemia , and hypocalcaemia . Allopurinol is the treatment of choice to prevent TLS by inhibiting uric acid production and preventing renal complications . Hydration and monitoring of electrolytes and renal function are also essential in managing TLS .
  • ➤ Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS) is a potentially fatal complication of chemotherapy for highly proliferative cancers like Burkitt lymphoma . It results from the rapid breakdown of tumour cells, leading to hyperuricaemia , hyperkalemia , hyperphosphatemia , and hypocalcaemia .

  • ➤ Allopurinol is the treatment of choice to prevent TLS by inhibiting uric acid production and preventing renal complications .
  • ➤ Allopurinol

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a racing heartbeat occurring intermittently for 6 months. She has a history of thyrotoxicosis, managed with propranolol and carbimazole. Investigations: ECG – shown below: Which is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Stimulating the cephalic end of a vagus nerve would causes the respiration to:

questions.text: Among the following, which property would play the most important role in determining the diffusibility of such a substance through a cell membrane?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lipid solubility

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cell membranes are composed primarily of phospholipid bilayers , which create a hydrophobic barrier to the passive diffusion of substances. Therefore, the lipid solubility of a substance is the most critical factor governing whether a water-insoluble (hydrophobic) compound can effectively cross the membrane.
  • • phospholipid bilayers
  • • hydrophobic barrier
  • • lipid solubility
  • • most critical factor
  • • water-insoluble (hydrophobic) compound
  • • Highly lipid-soluble molecules can dissolve in the hydrophobic core of the membrane and pass through via simple diffusion . This applies especially to nonpolar , uncharged , and hydrophobic molecules , which include water-insoluble drugs and lipid-based substances.
  • • lipid-soluble molecules
  • • simple diffusion
  • • nonpolar
  • • uncharged
  • • hydrophobic molecules
  • • water-insoluble drugs
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Molecular weight: While molecular weight can affect diffusion rate , it is less important than lipid solubility for nonpolar molecules. A large molecule that is highly lipid-soluble may still diffuse better than a small molecule that is water-soluble.
  • • Option A. Molecular weight:
  • • diffusion rate
  • • less important than lipid solubility
  • • Option C. Hydrated diameter: Hydrated diameter affects the movement of polar or ionized substances through aqueous pores or channels. It is not the limiting factor for a hydrophobic, water-insoluble substance , which diffuses directly through the lipid portion of the membrane.
  • • Option C. Hydrated diameter: Hydrated diameter
  • • polar or ionized substances
  • • hydrophobic, water-insoluble substance
  • • lipid portion
  • • Option D. Electrical charge: Charged molecules do not easily cross lipid bilayers due to electrostatic repulsion and hydrophilic nature. But in this case, the substance is water-insoluble , implying it is likely nonpolar and uncharged . Therefore, electrical charge is not relevant in determining its membrane diffusibility.
  • • Option D. Electrical charge: Charged molecules
  • • water-insoluble
  • • nonpolar and uncharged
  • • electrical charge is not relevant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipid solubility is the most important factor determining the ability of a water-insoluble substance to diffuse through a cell membrane, as only lipid-soluble molecules can pass freely through the phospholipid bilayer.

questions.text: A national drug regulatory agency inspects a batch of tablets labeled as containing 650 mg of paracetamol per dose. Upon chemical analysis, the tablets are found to contain only 350 mg of the active ingredient. The drug is manufactured and distributed under a legitimate brand name but fails to meet the labeled potency. Which of the following best describes the classification of this drug under regulatory definitions?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A national drug regulatory agency conducted an inspection of a batch of tablets labeled as containing 650 mg of paracetamol per dose. However, upon chemical analysis, the tablets were found to contain only 350 mg of the active ingredient.
  • • Even though the drug was manufactured and distributed under a legitimate brand name, it failed to meet the labeled potency because the actual content (350 mg) was different from the declared amount (650 mg).
  • • According to regulatory definitions, a drug is classified as a misbranded drug when there is a mismatch between the label and the actual content. Misbranding involves incorrect, false, or misleading labeling information. Here, the label falsely claims 650 mg, but the true content is only 350 mg, making it a misbranded drug.
  • • Thus, based on all facts — labeling error regarding the amount, despite being manufactured under a legitimate brand — the drug fits the classification of Misbranded drug.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A) Adulterant drug:
  • • Option A) Adulterant drug:
  • • An adulterant drug is one that contains undesired, inferior, harmful, or unauthorized substances, making it unsafe or harmful to health. In the given case, there is no mention of contamination or harmful substances in the tablet. The issue was only about incorrect labeling of the quantity of active ingredient (paracetamol), not contamination. Therefore, adulterant drug is incorrect.
  • • Option C) Spurious drug:
  • • Option C) Spurious drug:
  • • A spurious drug is one that is falsely claimed to be manufactured by another company or is a completely fake or counterfeit product. In this case, it is clearly stated that the drug is manufactured and distributed under a legitimate brand name, meaning it is not fake. Hence, the classification spurious drug is incorrect here.
  • • Option D) Substandard drug:
  • • Option D) Substandard drug:
  • • A substandard drug is a genuine drug that fails to meet quality specifications like strength, purity, or quality but without necessarily misleading labeling. Although the drug contains less paracetamol than expected, the key issue highlighted here is the mislabeling of strength (650 mg claimed vs. 350 mg present), not just quality failure. Therefore, substandard drug is incorrect because misbranding due to wrong labeling is the core issue.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • A misbranded drug is one where the label falsely represents the amount of active ingredient present in the product, even if the drug is manufactured and distributed under a legitimate brand name.
